Calculating proper lifespan: Users read approximately 1
character every 50 milliseconds. This means a message with 141
characters should have a lifespan of 7,050 milliseconds, or about
7 seconds (141 characters * 50 milliseconds).In cases where your
estimation is below the minimum lifespan, default to 5 seconds.
Likewise, for an estimate that exceed the maximum, default to 10
seconds.
Manual dismissal
hE Ee Close button: A Toast can also be dismissed by pressing or
clicking its close icon.
Swiping gesture: A Toast can also be dismissed by using a
swiping gesture. The direction of the swipe should move the
Toast off-screen in the opposite direction that it came in from
(e.g. Toasts that enter downwards from the top of the screen can
be dismissed by swiping the Toast upwards).
Interrupting auto-dismissal
When a Toast is interacted with, either by a pointer device or a
Message x keyboard focused state, the Toast will pause its auto-dismissal
timer. Upon mouse-out or loss of focus, the auto-dimiss timer will
WO start over.
Toast priority
When a Toast is triggered while another Toast is already present
on screen the previous Toast is removed instantly and replaced
by the new one. A user should only ever see one Toast at a time.
The more recent Toast should always be prioritised.

Use actions in Toast with caution
Actions in Toast can lead to an in-accessible user experience. For sighted keyboard
users with reduced mobility the temporary state of the Toast can be difficult to reach in
time. For users who have zoomed in browsers, or screen magnification software, a
Toast might not show up at all, or obscure the users flow, among other issues. For more
information see this article.
Therefore, a toast should ideally just contain a simple feedback message that isn't
essential to being able to progress with the users task at hand.
If you do need to use an action in Toast, keep in mind that the action should also be
available on the main page, read more in this section, action mapping. The copy for the
action should also always be descriptive, to further aid the feedback.

Toast vs. Modal
Toasts should only display brief, non-interruptive messages that confirm users' actions.
They can appear as instant feedback or asynchronous feedback as background
processes are completed (e.g. file upload). Use Modals instead when a situation
requires a user's direct attention, like displaying important information or prompting a
response.
